Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: SusChEM: Development of Governing Mechanistic and Kinetic Models for the Selective Oxidative Cleavage of Levulinic Acid Over Supported Vanadium Oxides

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

PI: Jesse Q Bond
Proposal #: 1454346
Institution: Syracuse University

This project aims to develop a strategy for producing succinic acid and maleic acid from biomass. Traditionally, these commodity chemicals are made by oxidizing components of crude oil or natural gas, which is challenging. Instead, it may be possible to produce them more efficiently and inexpensively from sugar molecules, which can be extracted from biomass. This approach would require that we understand the reasons why certain catalysts and precursors deliver the desired products, while others do not. We anticipate that a technology that converts biomass and biomass derivatives to valuable products could help with commercial development of biomass processing industries. An educational component of the project will build a connection between Syracuse University students and communities in the city of Syracuse through service projects. The education program includes public workshops designed to improve public scientific literacy by educating participants on topics in energy and resource sustainability. Workshops will also outline effective methods for reducing society?s dependence on fossil resources and technology?s role in sustainability. The workshops will be facilitated by Syracuse University students as part of their undergraduate curriculum. These students will also work on design projects that incorporate new, energy- and resource-efficient technologies into ongoing urban development initiatives. This will allow them to use their training to improve their community and demonstrate the beneficial societal impacts of a STEM education.

This award supports the study of gas-phase, aerobic oxidative cleavage of bifunctional levulinic acid (4-oxopentanoic acid) over supported vanadium oxides to yield C4 diacids. Diacid formation occurs through cleavage of the terminal C-C bond in levulinic acid, which is not generally observed in monofunctional ketone analogs, such as 2-pentanone. The central hypothesis is that the structure and bifunctionality of levulinic acid underlie unique interactions with VOx sites that shift selectivity toward terminal C-C cleavage. The project seeks to identify descriptors that govern C-C cleavage selectivity during ketone oxidation.

This project will consider the influence of VOx speciation by measuring rates and selectivities of oxidative ketone cleavage over VOx/Al2O3 catalysts in which VOx phase and degree of polymerization are controlled by varying vanadium loading. The roles of Br√∏nsted and Lewis acidity will be examined by studying oxidative cleavage over monolayer VOx/Al2O3 catalysts in which both acid site density and distribution are varied using acidic and basic modifiers. The influence of V-O-X bond character will be probed by comparing VOx sites on oxides that differ in reducibility. Isotopic tracing using 18O will identify the roles of lattice and chemisorbed oxygen during levulinic acid oxidation. Influences of ketone structure, steric interactions, and secondary functionality will be probed through a combination of kinetic and spectroscopic studies that contrast levulinic acid oxidation with that of various mono- and bifunctional ketone analogs. Electronic structure calculations will be used to build and parameterize a microkinetic model, which will reconcile first-principles expectations with experimental outcomes. Raman, UV-Vis, FTIR, and Temperature-Programmed spectroscopies (e.g., TPD, TPSR) will provide comprehensive characterization of site structure and chemical functionality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching aim of this project has been to elucidate the mechanism by which supported vanadium oxides facilitate selective methyl scission during the oxidative cleavage of levulinic acid to produce maleic anhydride. We have employed detailed kinetic analysis; infrared and Raman spectroscopy; NMR spectroscopy; and transient methods to definitively resolve this question and to further provide a mechanism for the oxidative scission of ketones on reducible and non-reducible Lewis acidic solid oxides.

As a primary outcome, we have demonstrated that levulinic acid can be converted to maleic anhydride in roughly 70% yield using aerobic oxidation over supported vanadium oxides.  This is potentially interesting as the oxidation of levulinic acid occurs at relatively mild conditions and achieves improved maleic anhydride selectivity relative to conventional butane oxidation. This work was highlighted in a Catalyzing Commercialization writeup in Chemical Engineering Progress (January 2021). The selectivity in this system is surprising when one considers that it requires methyl scission, whereas methylketone oxidation is typically >90% selective to internal bond scission. Through detailed kinetic and spectroscopic analysis, we have shown that levulinic acid oxidative scission is selective for methyl scission because levulinic acid undergoes facile intramolecular dehydration to form cyclic angelicalactones, which react through oxidative dehydrogenation and oxidative scission to produce maleic anhydride. In contrast, monofunctional methylketones cannot form heterocycles and so must react through an open chain pathway where alkyl scission is strongly kinetically favored.

Selectivity to maleic anhydride during the oxidation of levulinic acid is actually unique to levulinic acid, a C5 gamma-ketoacid, because of its structure and its bifunctionality. The combination of a C5 chain and a carbonyl in the gamma-position means that it is thermodynamically favorable for levuinic acid to dehydrate to form ring structures, namely angelicalactones, at typical reaction temperatures. Angelicalactones, in turn, are uniquely susceptible to facile oxidative dehydrogenation of the C4-C5 bond, which forms a relatively stable conjugated diene structure (protoanemonin). Once formed, because of its diene structure, protoanemonin is susceptible only to oxidative scission of its C4-C5 bond, i.e., the methyl group in levulinic acid. It is worth noting that we have found that protoanemonin can be prepared in approximately 60% yield under levulinic acid oxidation conditions by simple manipulation of space velocity. As a novel biogenic chemical intermediate, protoaneomin is interesting. It has diene and lactone functionalities, making it potentially attractive for the production of novel bio-based polymers. More recently, we have elucidated a general mechanism for the oxidative scission of ketones on vanadium oxides supported on gamma-Al2O3. In doing so, we highlight the mechanistic significance of Lewis acid sites, lattice oxygen, and gas-phase oxygen, which provides a rational basis for designing ketone oxidation catalysts and ketone oxidation reactors.

To date, this project has resulted in 3 peer-reviewed publications; 2 patents and/or pending patent applications; and multiple invited presentations and seminars. Results from this project have led to many new research directions in the area of reducible oxide catalysts, and we expect that additional publications will be forthcoming beyond the conclusion of this project. The project has supported a portion of thesis projects for 4 PhD students at Syracuse University. Educational outcomes have focused on the development of service learning courses that explore independent study projects in sustainability and engage undergraduate students in community outreach.
